body: Hi, can you provide more details on how/what did you use to load the MaskRCNN model? so as to better reproduce the exception issue. thanks!
Just for reference.. some previous related answers: [issue #1767:floating point exception](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/1767)

issue #1767 seams not related, because this happens on multiple environments with different linux base systems.

I can't share the C++ code, but it is a simple forward call. A quick verification can be done with the [onnx simplifier](https://github.com/daquexian/onnx-simplifier), which uses the onnxruntime internally:

```
> pip3 install onnx-simplifier
> ls
model.onnx
> python3 -m onnxsim model.onnx out.onnx
Simplifying...
Floating point exception (core dumped)
```

Here is a quick script causing the bug:

```python
import onnxruntime

session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession('./model.onnx', providers=['CPUExecutionProvider'])
```

rename.from: Floating point exception with MaskRCNN model
rename.to: Floating point exception with FasterSCNN model

body: I can reproduce this on my machine as well, but I have the same setup as @r0l1. FasterSCNN model from MMSegmentation causes a floating point exception in ORT

There is an AveragePool node in the model with stride as 0. Not sure what this means semantically as one can't really move in a stride of 0 while pooling along an axis. I suspect there was an issue with exporting this model to ONNX. Fixing this should atleast make the model load pass this issue.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9969784/151389053-2c5c3ddf-1029-4b7e-b580-0cdb7618c093.png)

The floating point exception itself comes from ONNX's shape inference while dividing by the said 0:

https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/50a1981dc3d50af13075cec33b08b4c87fb0e41f/onnx/defs/nn/defs.cc#L187

@hariharans29 thank you for the hint! Makes sense. I'll try to fix the model export. Should the onnxruntime engine do some input validation before starting the inference? This could cause DoS issues, if user models are loaded blindly...

issue.title: FasterSCNN ONNX export invalid Stride (0)

repository.name: mmsegmentation
repository.description: OpenMMLab Semantic Segmentation Toolbox and Benchmark.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Converting the FasterSCNN model to ONNX leads to an invalid average pool stride (=0). This causes the onnxruntime to segfault. Here is my issue at the onnxruntime engine repo: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/10402
I updated pytorch and did some tests, however the issue persists. Hope somebody can give a quick hint :)

**Reproduction**

1. What command or script did you run?
```none
python tools/pytorch2onnx.py \
fast_scnn.py \
--checkpoint pretrained-fast-scnn.pth \
--output-file model.onnx \
--input-img test.jpg \
--verify \
--shape 128 256
```

2. Did you make any modifications on the code or config? Did you understand what you have modified? -> Nothing changed. Tested different input sizes.
3. What dataset did you use? -> no dataset needed

**Environment**

1. Please run `python mmseg/utils/collect_env.py` to collect necessary environment information and paste it here.
2. You may add addition that may be helpful for locating the problem, such as
    - How you installed PyTorch [e.g., pip, conda, source]
    - Other environment variables that may be related (such as `$PATH`, `$LD_LIBRARY_PATH`, `$PYTHONPATH`, etc.)

I am using the Dockerfile of this repo. I tested the export with both PyTorch version 1.6.0 and 1.9.0, 1.10.0. All yielded the same results.

**Bug fix**

If you have already identified the reason, you can provide the information here. If you are willing to create a PR to fix it, please also leave a comment here and that would be much appreciated!

body:
> @hariharans29 thank you for the hint! Makes sense. I'll try to fix the model export. Should the onnxruntime engine do some input validation before starting the inference? This could cause DoS issues, if user models are loaded blindly...

Would have to think through how ORT can handle an invalid model. FWIW - The actual exception is coming from ONNX's shape inference (not from ORT itself): https://github.com/onnx/onnx and https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/50a1981dc3d50af13075cec33b08b4c87fb0e41f/onnx/defs/nn/defs.cc#L187. Maybe the shape inferencing function should have a check `if (strides[i] == 0) {  fail_shape_inference("Stride cannot be zero")}`

> The actual exception is coming from ONNX's shape inference (not from ORT itself):

How does this work for other backends as CUDA?

> Maybe the shape inferencing function should have a check if (strides[i] == 0) { fail_shape_inference("Stride cannot be zero")}

That would be a straightforward and quick solution. Should I prepare a quick pull request?

How does this work for other backends as CUDA?

Shape inferencing happens always

That would be a straightforward and quick solution. Should I prepare a quick pull request?

You may propose it to the ONNX repo

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.
